content:
Normally, Thunderbird would prompt if server is refusing due to incorrect password. All I can think of would be to either manually add the password to Thunderbird, or to remove what is there to allow a prompt. Here goes: - click settings>privacy&security - click saved passwords and then show passwords - highlight the incoming server row and rightclick and select 'edit password'

OR... - from same place, highlight the incoming and outgoing rows and delete.
creator: davidsk

content: when I deleted a folder, it appears as a sub folder of trash. Are you saying it is not there to simply move back where you want it?
creator: MattAuSupport

content: You could notify your email provider of the issue. This might also be the sender's problem if these error occur when sending to a large list of recipients.
creator: davidsk

content: David - thanks for your thoughts, but when I contacted Talktalk, they suggested I contact Thunderbird. The sender was sending only to me.
creator: colin.jannaway

content: That is an example of the level of support some email providers give. No email client could ever give that error message. The message is being generated by a TalkTalk server. I did a quick web search on this error message and noticed there are others out there who report to their email provider and are ignored. In this case, Thunderbird isn't even involved. Message goes from the sender's email server to the TalkTalk server which responds back. They are ignoring the problem.
creator: davidsk

content: Unless any other suggestions are received, perhaps I need to go back to Talktalk, and hopefully get a different "adviser".
creator: colin.jannaway

content: Yes, if there is web access to the message, tell them it's not coming there. Don't even mention Thunderbird.

content: Be sure you have Thunderbird set to allow cookies at settings>privacy&security when attempting to set up account, omit the password. That often works.
creator: davidsk

content: I have Accept cookies from sites and third party both selected.

content: I still get the yellow background message in account setup saying Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password. i have checked username (email address) and password, all correct after logging in via another browser where my password is not stored. So I know all details entered are correct.
creator: jasoncarroll1971

content: Did you enter the password and successfully have Thunderbird confirm the account?
creator: davidsk

content: That is, my suggestion is that you NOT use the password.
creator: davidsk

content: ok, theres are what steps I took.I open TBM, go to settings, click show cookies, and remove all relating to Google. Thenclicked saved passwords and removed the passwords for the account, click TBM and waited a while, reopened TBM and back to adding the account. Entered my name, email and normal password (not App password) Clicked continue Config found message shows. The popup shows my email address and I click next, and enter my password in the next window and click nexted. 2 step verification shows next, and I confirm on my mobile that it's me. the mozilla thunderbird email wants access to your google account, Click Allow for all access. Then the window closes and back in TBM in yellow the message states Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password.
creator: jasoncarroll1971

content: You are not understanding. I suggested to NOT enter the password. No guarantee, but it often works.

content: Ok, it sounds like the other person set up the email account and never shared the password. You need to contact the email provider to reset the password. If you share the information to the right of the @ sign in email address, I may be able to help you locate the email provider. Also, please click 'account settings' and then 'server settings' and let me know the name of the server name (see attached). The name may begin with imap or pop or possibly mail. We only support from this forum: no email or phone. Thank you.
creator: davidsk
